awd_titl_txt: CISE-MSI:RCBP-ED:CNS:Big Data and Cloud Computing Project Hatchery
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2).

The overarching goal of this project is to build the national pipeline of skilled workforce in the critical domain of Big Data and Cloud Computing technology. This workforce is crucial for the future advances in Data Analytics and Artificial Intelligence based priority areas of national interest. This project will provide Big Data and Cloud Computing technology skill-building opportunities for multidisciplinary students and faculty from underrepresented minority backgrounds at Cal Poly Pomona (Minority Serving Institution, MSI) as well as local alliances of Hispanic Service Institutions (HSI) and S-STEM programs.

This project will engage students in Big Data and Cloud Computing technology training and culminating projects early in their academic careers based on the Design Thinking approach, which focuses on understanding individual or community needs and creatively developing solutions to meet those needs. The project will use the Design Thinking concepts to connect students’ STEM curriculum to solving problems that benefit society using Big Data and Cloud Computing technologies- with students directly observing how their projects positively impact a specific community/end-user group. Students will see the potential impact of their education right away, instead of at the end of their academic career. In parallel, the project will provide research training and promote affinity groups for MSI faculty from four-year colleges to work with faculty members from research intensive institutions to foster research collaboration in Big Data and Cloud Computing domain and pursue collaborative external funding for research. The faculty exposure to the technology and resources supporting the Big Data and Cloud Computing research will build the Cal Poly Pomona and other participating HSI’s multidisciplinary capacity in this area to enable future research and education in this domain.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

por.por_cntn:
This program has prepared around 120 students from various disciplines such as Animal Sciences, Aerospace Engineering, Business, Computer Science, Kinesiology, and Psychology (to name a few) at Cal Poly Pomona (CPP) and other California State University (CSU) campuses on  the very crucial Big Data and Cloud Computing (BDCC) skills using the Cloud Bank based Amazon Web Services, Google Cloud Platform and Microsoft Azure platforms. The CPP participants have also completed a culminating project and presented the poster at the CPP Annual College of Science Research Symposium. Based on the training, a few participants have continued to work on the projects in the NSF REU on Big Data Security and Privacy over the summer and a few of them also proceeded to continue their education at the University of California (UC) PhD programs based on the impact of culminating research projects. The project has also played a pivotal role in establishing permanent CS classes in the BDCC domain which are integral part of the Data Science minor as well as a proposed Data Science and AI certificate.


The program has also trained faculty members from Geography and Anthropology, Hospitality Management, Technology and Operations Management, Economics and Aerospace Engineering on BDCC resources. The program has matched the faculty participants with Computer Science faculty members to collaboratively work on BDCC research projects of interdisciplinary significance, submit external funding proposals and successfully receive funding from State and Federal Agencies. We have also invited faculty members for research talks from University of California (UC) campuses to encourage cross-institutional collaborations and one such collaboration has successfully submitted proposals for federal funding in the domain of BDCC. We believe this project's impact will produce more sustainable collaborative projects in the near future.


Last Modified: 01/28/2025
Modified by: Mohammad I Husain
